6 /// <summary>
7 /// Negative Volume Index (NVI)
8 /// </summary>
9 /// <remarks>
10 /// Cumulative indicator that changes only when volume decreases from the previous day.
11 /// <list type="bullet">
12 /// <item><description>Assumption: "Smart money" is active on low volume days.</description></item>
13 /// <item><description>If Vol(t) < Vol(t-1): NVI = NVI_prev + (NVI_prev * ROC)</description></item>
14 /// <item><description>If Vol(t) >= Vol(t-1): NVI remains unchanged.</description></item>
15 /// </list>
16 /// </remarks>
17 public class NegativeVolumeIndex
18 {
19 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
20 private const decimal InitialValue = 1000m;
21​
22 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
23 {
24 Values.Clear();
25 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
26 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
27​
28 decimal nvi = InitialValue;
29 Values.Add(nvi);
30​
31 for (int i = 1; i < candleList.Count; i++)
32 {
33 if (candleList[i].Volume < candleList[i - 1].Volume && candleList[i - 1].Close != 0)
34 {
35 decimal roc = (candleList[i].Close - candleList[i - 1].Close) / candleList[i - 1].Close;
36 nvi = nvi + (nvi * roc);
37 }
38 Values.Add(nvi);
39 }
40 }
41​
42 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
43 {
44 var nvi = new NegativeVolumeIndex();
45 nvi.Calculate(candles);
46 return nvi.Values;
47 }
48 }
49}

1// =============================================================================
2// Logic Breakdown (NegativeVolumeIndex)
3// =============================================================================
4//
5// This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6// Negative Volume Index (NVI) technical indicator.
7// We explain *why* code is written this way and *how* data transforms
8// line-by-line, targeting programming beginners.
9//
10// [Core Concepts]
11//
12// 1. What is NVI?
13// [Origin] Created by Paul Dysart in the 1930s, popularized by Norman Fosback.
14// [Idea] "Smart money" (institutional investors) trades on QUIET days
15// when volume is LOW. Retail/crowd trades on high-volume days.
16// [Goal] Track what happens on low-volume days to follow smart money.
17//
18// 2. The Logic
19// [Rule] Only update NVI when today's volume is LESS than yesterday's.
20// [Why?] On low-volume days, the "informed" traders are more dominant.
21// On high-volume days, noise from retail trading dominates.
22//
23// 3. Calculation
24// [Formula]
25// If Volume[today] < Volume[yesterday]:
26// ROC = (Close[today] - Close[yesterday]) / Close[yesterday]
27// NVI = NVI × (1 + ROC)
28// Else:
29// NVI = Previous NVI (unchanged)
30//
31// [Initial Value] NVI starts at 1000 by convention.
32//
33// 4. Signal Interpretation (Fosback's Research)
34// [Rule] Compare NVI to its 255-day (1 year) moving average.
35//
36// | Condition | Implication |
37// |------------------|-----------------------------------|
38// | NVI > 255-day MA | 96% chance of bull market |
39// | NVI < 255-day MA | Higher probability of bear market |
40//
41// [Visual: NVI vs PVI]
42//
43// NVI: Updates only on LOW volume days → Tracks smart money
44// PVI: Updates only on HIGH volume days → Tracks the crowd
45//
46// Together, they help distinguish institutional vs retail behavior.
47//
48// =============================================================================
49​
50using System;
51using System.Collections.Generic;
52​
53namespace TechnicalIndicators
54{
55 // =============================================================================
56 // Logic Explanation: OHLCV Data Container
57 // =============================================================================
58 public readonly record struct CandleData(DateTime Timestamp, decimal Open, decimal High, decimal Low, decimal Close, long Volume);
59​
60 // =============================================================================
61 // Logic Explanation: NegativeVolumeIndex Class
62 // =============================================================================
63 public class NegativeVolumeIndex
64 {
65 // -------------------------------------------------------------
66 // Logic Explanation: Output and Constant
67 //
68 // [InitialValue] 1000 is a convention (arbitrary starting point).
69 // The absolute value doesn't matter; the TREND does.
70 // -------------------------------------------------------------
71 public List<decimal?> Values { get; } = new();
72 private const decimal InitialValue = 1000m;
73​
74 // =============================================================================
75 // Logic Explanation: Main Calculation Method
76 // =============================================================================
77 public void Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
78 {
79 // -------------------------------------------------------------
80 // Step 1: Cleanup & Setup
81 // -------------------------------------------------------------
82 Values.Clear();
83 var candleList = new List<CandleData>(candles);
84 if (candleList.Count == 0) return;
85​
86 // -------------------------------------------------------------
87 // Step 2: Initialize NVI
88 //
89 // [Note] First bar starts at InitialValue (1000).
90 // -------------------------------------------------------------
91 decimal nvi = InitialValue;
92 Values.Add(nvi);
93​
94 // -------------------------------------------------------------
95 // Step 3: Main Loop
96 //
97 // [Visual: Selective Update Logic]
98 //
99 // Day 1: Volume = 1000, NVI = 1000 (initial)
100 // Day 2: Volume = 800 → Volume DOWN → Update NVI
101 // Day 3: Volume = 1200 → Volume UP → No change
102 // Day 4: Volume = 700 → Volume DOWN → Update NVI
103 // -------------------------------------------------------------
104 for (int i = 1; i < candleList.Count; i++)
105 {
106 // [Condition] Volume decreased from yesterday
107 if (candleList[i].Volume < candleList[i - 1].Volume && candleList[i - 1].Close != 0)
108 {
109 // Calculate Rate of Change (ROC)
110 decimal roc = (candleList[i].Close - candleList[i - 1].Close) / candleList[i - 1].Close;
111
112 // Update NVI: NVI = NVI × (1 + ROC)
113 // = NVI + NVI × ROC
114 nvi = nvi + (nvi * roc);
115 }
116 // Else: Volume increased or unchanged → NVI stays the same
117​
118 Values.Add(nvi);
119 }
120 }
121​
122 // =============================================================================
123 // Logic Explanation: Static Convenience Wrapper
124 //
125 // [IPO Block]
126 // Input: IEnumerable<CandleData>
127 // Process: Creates instance, runs Calculate()
128 // Output: List of NVI values (cumulative from 1000)
129 // =============================================================================
130 public static List<decimal?> Calculate(IEnumerable<CandleData> candles)
131 {
132 var nvi = new NegativeVolumeIndex();
133 nvi.Calculate(candles);
134 return nvi.Values;
135 }
136 }
137}

1# =============================================================================
2# Logic Breakdown (Negative Volume Index)
3# =============================================================================
4#
5# This document provides a "Deep Dive" into the internal logic of the
6# Negative Volume Index (NVI). We explain *why* code is written this way
7# and *how* data transforms line-by-line.
8#
9# [Core Concepts]
10# 1. The "Smart Money" Theory
11# - Market folklore suggests that "Uninformed" crowds trade on high volume days.
12# - "Smart Money" (Institutions) accumulates positions quietly on low volume days.
13# - Therefore, NVI is designed to reflect what the "Smart Money" is doing.
14#
15# 2. Logic Rule
16# - If Volume < Previous Volume: The index is updated based on Price Change (ROC).
17# - If Volume >= Previous Volume: The index remains static (ignores the day).
18#
19# 3. Trend Signal
20# - NVI crossing above its 255-day EMA is often viewed as a Bull Market signal.
21#
22# =============================================================================
23​
24# -------------------------------------------------------------
25# Type-Level Explanation: NegativeVolumeIndex (class)
26#
27# [Why] Cumulative index that tracks "Smart Money" flow.
28# [What] A trend indicator based on volume contraction.
29# [How] Updates a cumulative index based on the percentage change in price only on days when volume decreases relative to the previous day; otherwise, the index remains unchanged.
30# [Who] Popularized by Norman Fosback.
31# [Where] Often used in conjunction with PVI (Positive Volume Index).
32# -------------------------------------------------------------
33class NegativeVolumeIndex:
34
35 # -------------------------------------------------------------
36 # Variable Definition: values
37 # [Role] The output time series of the index.
38 # [Type] List[float]. Starts at an arbitrary base (e.g., 1000).
39 # -------------------------------------------------------------
40 # values = []
41​
42 # -------------------------------------------------------------
43 # Constructor: __init__
44 # [Why] Initialize the storage for the index values.
45 # -------------------------------------------------------------
46 def __init__(self):
47 self.values = []
48​
49 # =============================================================================
50 # IPO: calculate
51 # =============================================================================
52 #
53 # [Input]
54 # - candles: List[dict] (Requires 'close' and 'volume')
55 #
56 # [Process]
57 # 1. Start with a base value of 1000.
58 # 2. Iterate through the bars starting from the second bar (index 1).
59 # 3. Compare current Volume vs Previous Volume.
60 # 4. If Volume Decreased: Apply the Price ROC to the Index.
61 # 5. Otherwise: Carry forward the previous Index value.
62 #
63 # [Output]
64 # - None (Populates 'values' list).
65 # =============================================================================
66 def calculate(self, candles):
67
68 # -------------------------------------------------------------
69 # Logic Step 1: Reset
70 # -------------------------------------------------------------
71 self.values.clear()
72
73 # [Fail Fast] Need at least 1 bar to start (though practical use needs 2)
74 if len(candles) == 0:
75 return
76​
77 # -------------------------------------------------------------
78 # Logic Step 2: Initialization
79 #
80 # [Why]
81 # Cumulative indices need a starting point.
82 # 1000 is a standard convention to avoid negative numbers early on.
83 # -------------------------------------------------------------
84 nvi = 1000.0
85
86 # First bar has no "previous volume" to compare, so we just set the seed.
87 self.values.append(nvi)
88​
89 # -------------------------------------------------------------
90 # Logic Step 3: Main Loop
91 #
92 # [Action] Iterate from the 2nd candle to the end.
93 #
94 # [Visual]
95 # Day 1: Vol=100 -> NVI=1000
96 # Day 2: Vol=90 (Decrease) -> Update NVI based on Price Change.
97 # Day 3: Vol=120 (Increase) -> Keep NVI same.
98 # -------------------------------------------------------------
99 for i in range(1, len(candles)):
100 current_close = candles[i]['close']
101 prev_close = candles[i - 1]['close']
102 current_vol = candles[i]['volume']
103 prev_vol = candles[i - 1]['volume']
104
105 # -------------------------------------------------------------
106 # Logic Step 3.1: Volume Comparison
107 #
108 # [Decision]
109 # Did volume drop compared to yesterday?
110 #
111 # [True Branch: Smart Money Active]
112 # Update the index.
113 #
114 # [False Branch: Crowd Active]
115 # Ignore price moves, keep index static.
116 # -------------------------------------------------------------
117 if current_vol < prev_vol and prev_close != 0:
118
119 # Logic Step 3.2: Calculate Rate of Change (ROC)
120 # Formula: (Current - Prev) / Prev
121 # Example: 105 - 100 / 100 = 0.05 (5% gain)
122 roc = (current_close - prev_close) / prev_close
123
124 # Logic Step 3.3: compounding
125 # nvi_new = nvi_old + (nvi_old * roc)
126 # Note: This means if price drops 5%, NVI drops 5%.
127 nvi = nvi + (nvi * roc)
128
129 # -------------------------------------------------------------
130 # Logic Step 3.4: Store Result
131 # -------------------------------------------------------------
132 self.values.append(nvi)
133​
134# =============================================================================
135# Static Wrapper Function
136# =============================================================================
137#
138# [Why] Functional API for ease of use.
139# [Usage] results = calculate(candles)
140# =============================================================================
141def calculate(candles):
142 instance = NegativeVolumeIndex()
143 instance.calculate(candles)
144 return instance.values
